title: Economic Development tools for the ERC Fellows
text:
The data team at CORI created the Economic Development Tool to aid the Fellows in their work by providing analysis and data on a wide variety of economic indicators.

Ad hoc data support
If you have any questions or would like additional help integrating any of this data into your workflow, please reach out to Drew (drew.rosebush@ruralinnovation.us) or Brittany (brittany.kainen@ruralinnovation.us) on the Rural Innovation data team.
You are also welcome to attend our open office hours, which are held on the first and third Thursdays of every month.

title: Local Economy
text:
Access NERDE’s State Data Explorer, County Data Explorer, and Tract Data Explorer
NERDE’s Data Explorers provide detailed economic and demographic data at 3 different geographic levels. The platform features interactive visualizations on a wide range of data, including employment rates, income levels, and population dynamics, allowing for a nuanced understanding of local conditions. Users can select multiple areas of interest, in order to compare and analyze trends across different geographic areas.

Years: Various data years
Geographic level: State, County, and Tract
Territories available: Puerto Rico

title: Business
text:
Data Axle provides comprehensive and accurate business data, which helps organizations enhance their marketing strategies and target the right audience more effectively. Its robust analytics tools enable users to gain valuable insights into customer behaviors and market trends, leading to more informed decision-making.
This is a subscription-based resource that you may be able to access through your local library. To see if your library subscribes, search for Reference Solutions (formerly ReferenceUSA), Data Axle’s product for libraries, on your library’s website.
Here are some general tips that may help you find Data Axle on your local library’s website:
First, go to your library’s website.


Navigate to tabs like “Research”, “Digital Resources”, or “Databases.” If the digital resources are sorted by topic, select the topic called something like “Business.”


Once you access your business-related digital resources, search for the title “Reference Solutions” (it may also appear as “ReferenceUSA”.) Then follow your library’s instructions to open Reference Solutions. You will likely need to enter your library card number.


If you can’t find this resource at your local library, check your state-level library system to see if it’s still available to you.

title: Environment
text:
Access the USDA’s Natural Amenities Scale dataset
The USDA’s “Natural Amenities Scale” quantifies the attractiveness of geographic areas based on natural features such as climate, topography, and water bodies. This scale ranks counties across the United States, helping to identify regions with high natural appeal that can influence migration patterns and economic development.

Year: 1990
Geographic level: County (excluding HI and AK)
Territories available: (This source only includes the lower 48 and D.C.)

title: Environment
text:
Outdoor Recreation Economy
Access Headwaters Economics’ Outdoor Recreation Economy by State report
This Headwaters Economics report examines the economic impact of outdoor recreation across the United States, highlighting its contributions to jobs, wages, and overall state economies. It provides state-by-state data and analysis, showcasing the significance of outdoor activities such as hiking, camping, and fishing in driving economic growth.

Year: 2022
Geographic level: State
Territories available: (This source only includes the 50 states and D.C.)

title: Environment
text:
Air Quality
Access the EPA’s Air Quality Statistics Report datasets
The EPA’s Air Quality Statistics Report offers detailed information on air quality trends and pollutants in the United States, summarizing data collected from monitoring stations nationwide. It highlights key indicators such as levels of particulate matter, ozone, and other harmful substances, providing insights into air quality improvements or deteriorations over time.

Years: 1980-2024
Geographic levels: County and City (the Census calls these “core-based statistical areas”)
Territories available: Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands

title: Environment

Water Quality
Access the EPA’s Water Quality data portal
The EPA’s Water Quality Portal is a comprehensive online resource that provides access to a vast array of water quality data from various federal, state, and tribal agencies. It enables users to explore and analyze information related to water monitoring, assessment, and standards.

Years: Various data years
Geographic level: County
Territories available: Puerto Rico, Northern Mariana Islands, U.S. Virgin Islands, Guam, and American Samoa

title: Health
text:
Access the County Health Rankings maps and data
County Health Rankings provide a snapshot of the overall health and well-being of communities across different counties. Published annually, these rankings assess a wide range of factors including health outcomes (such as premature death and quality of life), health behaviors (like smoking and physical activity), clinical care, social and economic conditions (such as education and employment), and the physical environment. The rankings help identify disparities between counties and highlight areas for improvement. By offering this data, they aim to inform local health initiatives, guide policy decisions, and promote efforts to enhance public health across regions.

Years: Editions are available each year 2011-2024
Geographic level: County
Territories available: (This source only includes the 50 states and D.C.)

title: Health
text:
Food Access Research Atlas
Access the USDA’s Food Access Research Atlas map
The USDA’s Food Access Research Atlas is a comprehensive tool designed to help understand and analyze food access in the United States. It provides data on various aspects of food accessibility, including the availability of grocery stores, supermarkets, and other food retailers, as well as factors like income and transportation. By mapping these elements, the Atlas helps identify areas with limited access to healthy food options, often referred to as “food deserts.” This information supports policymakers, researchers, and community organizations in developing strategies to improve food access and address nutritional disparities.

Year: 2019 (Updated 2023)
Geographic level: Census Tract
Territories available: (This source only includes the 50 states and D.C.)
crumbs: ERC Economic development tool and resources

title: Health
text:
HRSA Map
Access the Health Resources & Services Administration map tool
The Health Resources & Services Administration (HRSA) Map Tool is an interactive platform designed to visualize and analyze health resource distribution across the United States. It provides data on healthcare facilities, such as health centers, hospitals, and specialized services, along with information on health workforce availability and health outcomes. The tool aims to support decision-making by highlighting areas with unmet health needs and guiding the allocation of resources to improve healthcare access and services in underserved communities.

Years: Various data years (Updated 2024)
Territories available: Several layers are available for Puerto Rico, Northern Mariana Islands, U.S. Virgin Islands, Guam, and American Samoa

title: Introduction to Additional Resources
text:
In order to assist Fellows who require data that is not supported by the tool, we have assembled a vetted catalog of research and data. This catalog includes resources on the following themes…
Community Advocacy
This section contains a resource to help users asses a community’s leadership and ability to access funding for infrastructure projects.
Health
This section contains a variety of resources to help users survey the landscape of this topic. There are resources on health outcomes, health care access, and food desserts.
Environment
This section contains resources on the natural environment. There is both information about natural amenities from a recreation standpoint and from a health standpoint.
Infrastructure
This section contains two interactive tools created by CORI related to broadband. One of these tools can also help users understand potential environmental hazards in their area. This section also contains a resource on child care access.
Local Economy
This section contains a resource that provides an overview of the local economy. Though much of this information is also available in CORI’s Economic Development Tool, this resource may supplement the economic data available in CORI’s tool.
Business
This section helps users access a vetted list of active businesses (with details about the business) in a given area. This section does not provide direct access to the resource, but it does guide users through finding and accessing the resource.

title: Infrastructure
text:
Access CORI’s Broadband Climate Risk Mitigation Tool and data
CORI’s Broadband Climate Risk Mitigation Tool helps users evaluate the level of risk that weather events pose to future broadband infrastructure and identify the type of weather events that are the greatest threats. The tool does this by analyzing historical building loss due to extreme weather.

Years: Various data years (Updated 2023)
Geographic levels: Tract and County
Territories available: Puerto Rico, Northern Mariana Islands, U.S. Virgin Islands, Guam, and American Samoa

title: Infrastructure
text:
Broadband Service Map
Access CORI’s Interactive Broadband Service Map and data
CORI created the Interactive Broadband Service Map to support efficient initial assessments of eligibility for BEAD funding, but may aid others in understanding the broadband landscape in their regions. This map contains various block-level layers with useful information, including broadband service speeds, previous federal funding for broadband infrastructure, and internet service providers (IPSs.)

Years: Various data years (Updated 2024)
Geographic level: Census block
Territories available: Puerto Rico, Northern Mariana Islands, U.S. Virgin Islands, Guam, and American Samoa

title: Infrastructure
text:
Child Care Desserts
Access the Center for American Progress’s Child Care Desserts report and interactive map
The Center for American Progress defines a “child care dessert” as “any census tract with more than 50 children under age 5 that contains either no child care providers or so few options that there are more than three times as many children as licensed child care slots.” Their Child Care Deserts map highlights areas in the United States where access to affordable and quality child care is severely limited. It visualizes the distribution of child care providers relative to the number of children needing care, allowing users to identify regions facing significant shortages.

Year: 2015
Geographic level: State, County, and Tract
Territories available: (This source only includes the 50 states and D.C.)
crumbs: ERC Economic development tool and resources

title: Community Advocacy
text:
Access Headwaters Economics’ Rural Capacity Index map and data
The Rural Capacity Index is a measure designed to evaluate the ability of rural areas to support infrastructure and climate resilience projects. It assesses various factors such as economic resources and local governance. By providing a comprehensive view of rural capacities, it aims to enhance strategic planning and support targeted interventions for sustainable development. Though the index was developed to assess the capacity of rural communities, all U.S. communities receive a score.

Years: Various data years (Updated 2024)
Geographic levels: County, County Subdivision (these borders are similar to municipal borders in several states), Community (the Census calls these “Places”), and Tribal Areas (the Census calls these “American Indian Area/Alaska Native Area/Hawaiian Home Lands”)
Territories available: (This source only includes the 50 states and D.C.)
crumbs: ERC Economic development tool and resources

title: Changelog
text:
2024-10-11 updates for Version 2

Enable selection of multiple primary counties
Make the state and U.S. comparisons optional
Add an optional comparison that allows users to select all counties of a given urbanization level
Allow users to download the underlying data for each chart using a “Download data” button
Allow users to view the exact figures within each line chart by hovering over the desired line at a given year
Expand the “Employment by industry” chart from the top 5 industries to the top 10
Add geographic comparisons to the “Share of employment by sector” chart
Change the chart type of the “Average compensation per worker” chart from a bar chart with data from 2022 to a line chart with data from 2017-2022
Change the chart type of the “Real GDP per worker” chart from a bar chart with data from 2022 to a line chart with data from 2017-2022
Add the counts of computer and math workers in each geography to the bar chart labels in the “Tech employment” chart
Add an “Employment by occupation” chart to the Workforce section
Add a “Venture capital per capita” chart to the Entrepreneurship section
Add a “Business applications” chart to the Entrepreneurship section
Add a “Cost-burdened renters” chart to the Infrastructure section
Add a “Cost-burdened owners” chart to the Infrastructure section
Add a “Housing permits” chart to the Infrastructure section
Add a “Quality of life” chart to the Infrastructure section
Remove the “Share of employment in tradable services” chart, as this information is now in the “Share of employment by sector” chart
Remove the “Race and ethnicity (race alone)” chart, which only counts people who identified with just one race and are not Hispanic or Latino
Add the number of venture capital-backed businesses from 2019-23 to the “Key statistics” of the Entrepreneurship section
Add the number of patents granted from 2014-23 to the “Key statistics” of the Entrepreneurship section
Update data for the “Broadband service” chart with the latest release (Dec. 2023) of FCC Broadband Data Collection data
